subject: Orthopedics and Sports Medicine

items.abstract: <jats:p>Taking statins can cause increase in the level of aspartate and alanine aminotransferase. The aim of this study was to assess the usefulness of melatonin in counteracting the adverse hepatic events from statins.<jats:italic> Methods</jats:italic>. The research program included 60 patients (aged 47–65 years, 41 women and 19 men) with hyperlipidemia taking atorvastatin or rosuvastatin at a dose of 20–40 mg daily. The patients were randomly allocated in two groups. Group I (<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M1"><mml:mi>n</mml:mi><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">30</mml:mn></mml:math>) was recommended to take the same statin at a standardized daily dose of 20 mg together with melatonin at a dose of <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M2"><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">2</mml:mn><mml:mo>×</mml:mo><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">5</mml:mn></mml:math> mg. Group II (<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M3"><mml:mi>n</mml:mi><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">30</mml:mn></mml:math>) patients took statin with placebo at the same dose and time of the day. Follow-up laboratory tests (AST, ALT, GGT, and ALP) were evaluated after 2, 4, and 6 months of treatment.<jats:italic> Results</jats:italic>. In Group I the levels of all enzymes decreased after 6 months, particularly AST, <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M4"><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">97</mml:mn><mml:mtext>,</mml:mtext><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">2</mml:mn><mml:mo>±</mml:mo><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">19</mml:mn><mml:mtext>,</mml:mtext><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">1</mml:mn></mml:math> U/L versus <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M5"><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">52</mml:mn><mml:mtext>,</mml:mtext><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">8</mml:mn><mml:mo>±</mml:mo><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">12</mml:mn><mml:mtext>,</mml:mtext><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">3</mml:mn></mml:math> U/L (<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M6"><mml:mi>p</mml:mi><mml:mo><</mml:mo><mml:mtext>0,001</mml:mtext></mml:math>); ALT, <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M7"><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">87</mml:mn><mml:mtext>,</mml:mtext><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">4</mml:mn><mml:mo>±</mml:mo><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">15</mml:mn><mml:mtext>,</mml:mtext><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">6</mml:mn></mml:math> U/L versus <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M8"><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">49</mml:mn><mml:mtext>,</mml:mtext><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">8</mml:mn><mml:mo>±</mml:mo><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">14</mml:mn><mml:mtext>,</mml:mtext><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">5</mml:mn></mml:math> U/L (<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M9"><mml:mi>p</mml:mi><mml:mo><</mml:mo><mml:mtext>0,001</mml:mtext></mml:math>); and GGT, <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M10"><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">84</mml:mn><mml:mtext>,</mml:mtext><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">1</mml:mn><mml:mo>±</mml:mo><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">14</mml:mn><mml:mtext>,</mml:mtext><mml:mn fontstyle="italic">8</mml:mn></mml:math> U/L versus 59,6 U/L (<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M11"><mml:mi>p</mml:mi><mml:mo><</mml:mo><mml:mtext>0,001</mml:mtext></mml:math>).<jats:italic> Conclusion</jats:italic>. Melatonin exerts a hepatoprotective effect in patients taking statins.</jats:p>
title: The Effects of Melatonin on Elevated Liver Enzymes during Statin Treatment

items.abstract: <jats:p><em>Chaerophyllum cicutaria</em> is an andromonoecious member of the Umbelliferae</em> family. Apart from male flowers it also produces numerous hermaphrodite flowers the ovaries of which fail to transform into fruits. Almost one quarter of such non-fruiting hermaphrodites reveal an abnormal structure of their ovaries and or ovules while the development of others is arrested without visible structural changes. Twelve abnormalities are distinguished and their distribution among plants from various populations of the species is described. Presumed consequences of the abnormalities are discussed.</jats:p>
title: Occurrence of abnormalities in the ovary and ovule structure and their effect on fruit production in Chaerophyllum cicutaria Vill. (Umbelliferae)
Relationship between electronic structure and geometry of silanethiols and their derivatives: Elucidation of copper group silanethiolates
